contextId.occurrenceNote: A father teaches his child using poetry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases have the same meaning. It is implied that the person is strongly asking Yahweh for understanding. Alternate translation: "If you urgently ask God and plead for understanding" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: If you cry out for understanding and raise your voice for it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both phrases have the same meaning. These similes emphasize the great effort a person should make to understand what is wise. Alternate translation: "if you seek understanding with as much effort as you search for a valuable object" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: if you seek it like you would seek silver and search for understanding as you would seek hidden treasures

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means basically the same thing as the first part of the sentence. Alternate translation: "delight in doing what they know is evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: delight in the perversities of evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks as a father teaching his child using poetry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase says in positive terms what the previous phrase says in negative terms. Here the word "heart" represents the mind. The word "teachings" can be translated as a verb. Alternate translation: "always remember what I teach you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: keep my teachings in your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases express the same idea to make the student pay attention. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: listen to me ... do not turn away from listening

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases express the same idea and emphasize how much this person disliked what the teacher had said. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I hated instruction ... my heart despised correction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and refer to the person's community that has gathered together either 1) to worship God or 2) to judge him for his offense. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: in the midst of the assembly, among the gathering of the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The writer speaks of a man sleeping only with his wife as if he drank water only from his own cistern or well. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: water from your own cistern ... running water from your own well

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that God knows everything that everyone does. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: sees everything ... watches all the paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Do not let your eyes sleep; do not let your eyelids slumber." These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize how important it is not to be lazy. It is also stated negatively for even more emphasis. Alternate translation: "Stay awake, and do what you can" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.glQuote: Give your eyes no sleep and your eyelids no slumber

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are repeated to show how responsible the ant is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: it prepares its food in the summer ... during the harvest it stores up what it will eat

contextId.occurrenceNote: The teacher uses these questions to scold the lazy person for sleeping too much. Alternate translation: "Wake up, you lazy person! Get out of your bed!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How long will you sleep ... When will you rise from your sleep?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. They can be stated as complete sentences. Alternate translation: "I will just sleep a little longer. Let me sleep lightly a little longer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: A little sleep, a little slumber

contextId.occurrenceNote: This whole verse is a parallelism that emphasizes that God hates several things and not just one. Alternate translation: "six things that Yahwah hates; seven things that" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: six things that Yahweh hates, seven that

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases on the one hand mean the same thing. On the other hand, the repeated emphasis on both "father" and "mother" explicitly includes women in the whole teaching-learning process. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: obey the command of your father ... do not forsake the teaching of your mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases are used together to emphasize that the lessons are valuable all the time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: When you walk ... when you sleep ... when you wake up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The repetition of these phrases is to show that the lessons are valuable for all sorts of things. It also speaks of those lessons as if they were people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: they will guide you ... they will watch over you ... they will teach you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases mean basically the same thing, and together they show the various types of lessons a father and a mother teach. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the commands ... the teaching ... the corrections that come by instruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the same as the sentence before it. It strengthens the first warning. Alternate translation: "do not leave the right path in order to go on her paths" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: do not be led astray onto her paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases basically mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize that the woman's victims will be destroyed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: on the paths to Sheol ... down to the dark bedrooms of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases basically mean the same thing. Wisdom is described as having a home; possible meanings of "watching" are 1) a wise person waits outside wisdom's home in the morning in order to serve her, or 2) a wise person waits outside wisdom's house for her to come and teach him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: watching every day at my doors, waiting beside the posts of my doors

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases basically say the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Whoever disciplines ... whoever rebukes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases basically say the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Give to a wise person ... teach a righteous person

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases basically mean the same thing and are used to emphasize the great benefits wisdom has. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: your days will be multiplied, and years of life will be added to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two expressions basically mean the same thing, which is repeated to show how useless the foolish woman is. Alternate translation: "she does not know anything at all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: she is untaught and knows nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: Many verses in Chapter 10 are contrasting parallelisms (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Many verses in Chapter 11 are contrasting parallelisms (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] throughout this chapter. Verses 1-15 contrast wisdom and foolishness.
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines are parallel and it is implied that the man in the first line is a wise man. Alternate translation: "The words of a wise man's mouth are deep waters; ... the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: The words of a man's mouth are deep waters; ... the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize what is said. They can be combined. Alternate translation: "A person is satisfied by the results of the good things that he says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: From the fruit of his mouth one's stomach is filled; with the harvest of his lips he is satisfied

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same and are repeated to emphasize how important it is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Listen to advice and accept instruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize the danger of too much alcohol. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Wine is a mocker and strong drink is a brawler

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases basically mean the same thing and are combined to emphasize how bad this is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh hates unequal weights and dishonest scales are not good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. Using physical punishment to correct a person is spoken of as if the evil were dirt and the beatings cleansed him. Alternate translation: "Beating a person who has done wrong will correct him and cause him to be a better person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Blows that make a wound cleanse away evil and beatings make the innermost parts clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Be sure you know the condition of your flocks and be concerned about your herds
